content:
Horrible. I'm very salty.
Nowhere mentioned that angles should sum up to 360 or they not gonna compose a cyclic quadrilateral.
And no test cases where the sum of all angles equals 360 but the sum of the two opposite angles are not the same for both pair of angles.

I've edited so it's all good now.

You may argue that specifying that sum of all angles makes it too easy. I'll answer that if you gonna put a definition of a term in the statement you should put all relevant info in here. Not a part of it but all of it. Or at least specify that it's Euclidean geometry so It's not ambiguous. Becouse in non-Euclidean geometry you can have sum of all angles in cyclic quadrilateral be >360.

Imagine the amount of frustration I've got when a test failed just because I've assumed that I've been given a full definition. Got 88%. Checked out the solution of the 100% first place and it's the 'check if all sum is 360' solution that shouldn't even work.
You should also probably mention that the sums are equal to 180°.

The check where the pairs of angles don't add up to 180 previously only existed in Validator 4, so I changed that and moved the check to new Test 5 and Validator 5. This way players will know before submitting they still need to handle that case.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Is it possible for about 6 people to solve it? I think it's the right level.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and quick, but not too easy. I like it.
Math is always welcome!

I think you should mention that the pairs are (a, c) and (b, d) in the statement. Or may be give an example with the calculations. 

Shortest mode seems suitable too.

Guys please give a comment and give your opinion.
It will really help.
 And also please vote it.

the angles may be listed in any order so mentioning the pairs as (a,c) and (b,d) would just against the description. 
you must find if these angles in some order would work
but shortest mode change will be done ASAP.
